title: Nat Perrin
text:
Nat Perrin (March 15, 1905 – May 9, 1998) was an American comedy film, television and radio screenwriter, producer and director who contributed gags and storylines to several <a href="Marx%20Brothers">Marx Brothers</a> films and co-wrote the script for the film "<a href="Hellzapoppin%27%20%28film%29">Hellzapoppin'</a>" (1941) adapted from <a href="Hellzapoppin%20%28musical%29">the stage musical</a>. He is credited with writing the screenplay or story outline for over 25 films, including "<a href="The%20Big%20Store">The Big Store</a>" (1941), "<a href="The%20Great%20Morgan">The Great Morgan</a>" (1945), and "<a href="Song%20of%20the%20Thin%20Man">Song of the Thin Man</a>" (1947), as well as several television series.
Biography.
Perrin was a registered attorney who never practiced, he instead worked in the publicity department for <a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> in 1930. He often told the story of how he made his way into <a href="Groucho%20Marx">Groucho Marx</a>'s dressing room in 1931 with a forged letter of introduction from <a href="Moss%20Hart">Moss Hart</a>. Groucho was impressed with Perrin, and arranged for him to be hired by <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount Pictures</a> for the film "<a href="Monkey%20Business%20%281931%20film%29">Monkey Business</a>" (1931). The two would go on to become lifelong friends. In the late 1930s, Perrin produced for <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia Pictures</a>, moving to <a href="Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer">Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer</a> in the 1940s. 
In the early 1950s, he became a producer for such TV shows as "<a href="The%20Red%20Skelton%20Show">The Red Skelton Show</a>" (run 1951-1971) and the anthology series "<a href="Death%20Valley%20Days">Death Valley Days</a>" (run 1952-1970). He produced and was head writer for "<a href="The%20Addams%20Family%20%281964%20television%20series%29">The Addams Family</a>" series from 1964–1966.
Beginning in the late 1970s and well into his later years, Perrin taught screenwriting and film history at <a href="California%20State%20University%20Northridge">California State University Northridge</a>.
His lifelong friendship with Groucho Marx, for whom he also wrote the "<a href="Flywheel%2C%20Shyster%2C%20and%20Flywheel">Flywheel, Shyster, and Flywheel</a>" radio shows, came to a close when Perrin served as temporary conservator of the comedian's estate in 1977.
